title: Red Cross will stop providing first aid at festivals and marathons in new cost-cutting drive
text:
The British Red Cross will stop providing first aid at events such as marathons and festivals in a cost-cutting drive.

The charity, which was set up to offer support in crises, will no longer take part in events from March but will direct funds to other parts of its operation.

Bosses said providing first-aid volunteers for events cost £1.8million a year, despite the Red Cross often charging organisers. It has provided first aid at festivals such as Glastonbury.

A British Red Cross charity shop in Chichester (pictured). The charity, which was set up to offer support in crises, will no longer take part in events from March but will direct funds to other parts of its operation

Chief executive Michael Adamson said: ‘In recent years, we have seen increasing pressures on both our income and the demands for our assistance.

‘Our event first aid work has been running at a financial loss for some time and this is diverting vital funds from our efforts to provide emergency support for major domestic and global crises.

‘So it is with real sadness that we have taken the very difficult decision to close our event first aid service.’

He said the Red Cross was working with St John Ambulance to transfer volunteers who wished to continue offering first aid at events, with around 55 staff expected to be involved.
description: British Red Cross will stop providing first aid at events such as marathons and festivals from March as bosses say providing the first aid volunteers for events such as Glastonbury costs £1.8m.
